definitions.definition: the ability to deal with difficult or embarrassing situations carefully and without doing or saying anything that will annoy or upset other people

examples.text: Settling the dispute required great tact and diplomacy.
She is not exactly known for her tact.
The incident should have been handled with more tact by the police.
The situation called for considerable tact.
Their host, who was the soul of tact, never mentioned the incident again.

wordOrigin: mid 17th cent. (denoting the sense of touch): via French from Latin tactus ‘touch, sense of touch’, from tangere ‘to touch’.
